title: What songs are easy to play on one instrument, but difficult on another? - Quora

response.answer_text: Have you heard P. D. Q. Bach’s Pervertimento for bag pipes, bicycle, and garden hose? Don’t miss the Minuet for an example of bag pipes playing a violin line. It’s really something. In J. S. Bach’s Toccata and Fugue in D-Minor, the theme of the fugue seems pretty obviously composed for the pedal board of the organ. Using two feet, it’s a natural. Also, on an organ one would configure the pedal part in octaves—8-foot plus 16-foot, or maybe 16-foot plus 32-foot pipes. Try it with one hand on the piano, however, in octaves—not so easy! Organ pieces, in general, seem very hard to reproduce on a piano. There are some pretty piano arrangements of Cesar Franck’s Prelude, Fugue, and Variation originally for organ, but—at least in my hands—none of them capture the sense of serenity—majestic but gentle—of the organ. Guitar chords in popular music are, perhaps because of how its strings are tuned, voiced with a 4th in the bass and sometimes with another 4th above that. An easy way to play an A7 chord on the guitar begins with a low E (the lowest string of the instrument), then the open A string, then another E played in the D string, the open G string, a C# on the B string, and the open E string on top. (I can barely play the guitar, and, maybe this isn’t at all the natural or easiest way to play this chord on the guitar—I’m sorry, I don’t mean to give false information, but, I’m sure that in general guitar chords are often voiced in this kind of way.). So, if you’d like to accompany yourself playing John Lennon’s Julia on the piano, you may find that it sounds more like the original if you voice your accompaniment according to the layout of the guitar strings (and more or less centered in octave below Middle C). In the simplest of cases, think of the development section of Schubert’s Unfinished Symphony—those mournful, sustained clarinet notes. A singer or a wind player or even a string player can sustain a single note for a long time. They can all sing. Can you do this with a guitar or a piano? (You can do it with an electric guitar, however! I’ve heard an electric guitar that sounds at times like a trumpet.) Quiet, sustained string chords are similarly difficult to render on a piano, such as in accompaniment to operas. Quiet, tremolo string chords are also difficult to render, perhaps surprisingly—one might thing that piano tremolo would do it, and, maybe in the hands of better players than I it succeeds, but, I cannot get that quiet, slight dryness of the string tremolo. Pieces by Bach seem to survive transcription pretty well (except for things like the organ pedal parts, perhaps). There’s something infinitely adaptable built in to that music. But, everything has its limits. I wouldn’t care to hear the C-Major first Prelude from The Well-Tempered Clavier played on the bag pipes.

One example that readily comes to mind is playing rags on a simple instrument like a recorder versus a more advanced instrument like a clarinet. I played rags on my alto recorder with my mother on the piano and found it very challenging because rag composers love accidentals and my recorder music had a plethora of them. The recorder lacks the keys and alternative fingerings of more advanced woodwinds like the clarinet and oboe (I know because I also play clarinet and oboe) to help facilitate awkward passages. But challenges are always fun. I also think it is easier to improvise on the cornet or trumpet than an instrument like the clarinet and violin which has so many intricate fingerings with which to contend, whereas on the cornet or trumpet there are only three valves or buttons that stand between your mental processing and actualizing music. I haven’t read this anywhere but just base it on my own experience in playing the instruments. Also on any song the oboe is more difficult especially in the middle range than a clarinet, because the clarinet has an orderly intuitive fingering progression whereas the oboe skips around on what should be the intuitive progression of notes, especially with the Bflat, B, C, plus you have the infamous slide between half holes on a few notes in the middle range right above that which keep you continuously slipping and sliding around so to speak. But, like I said before, challenges are fun and make life interesting.
